title: Can I get into college with a 1.7 GPA, or should I do a community college first? - Quora
tags: Grade Point Average and University Admissions

response.answer_text: I almost flunked out of high school, and started community college on probation, but eventually earned my degree in Accounting at CSU Hayward when it was a small school with about 3,000 students. It’s now much larger with about 14,000 students, but felt I really got a good education. I started as a Field Auditor for Florsheim Shoe Company, and after 3.5 years was promoted to Audit Manager with a hefty salary increase, but we had to move to Chicago from California. After 3 years, we missed family, friends and the climate, so we moved back to California. It turned out fine, because I was controller for a couple of small companies, then started doing small business consulting. That’s where I enjoyed my work the most, and earned good money. I was able to travel the world, and retired early. Don’t let the 1.7 GPA discourage you, but you need to really put in the time to study more than you ever did in your life. It’ll all be worth it; trust me. BTW, start with community college to increase your skills in English composition and math. You’ll need at least College Algebra. In Business, I had to take a course in Statistics. Never had to use it in any of my jobs. Also, I learned that Accounting majors put more time into their studies, and that helps with other courses that you take. Good luck. Believe me, luck has much to do with one’s success. Being at the right place at the right time always helps. I was one good example of that. When I majored in Accounting, I had four job offers before I even graduated. I don’t believe that’s true any more. The following article is encouraging. Give it a read. What is the Job Outlook for Accounting Graduates? - Top Accounting Degrees

I personally do not know of any colleges that accept a 1.7 GPA and I was under the impression that must public schools require at least a 2.0 GPA to graduate. The transition from high school to college is extremely challenging, especially the first two semesters. Looking back at my college career, I did nothing but study the first several years. Actually all four years. If you are determined to go to college, I would start by taking either a course online to see how it goes, then ease into taking 1 or 2 courses at a local community college. If you succeed at those then consider going full time. College isn’t for anyone and that’s not meant to be a negative comment. There are plenty of people that have gone straight to the work force and done incredible things with their life. Another option could be to consider learning a trade. There’s a lot less schooling involved and you can enter the work force very quickly. Moreover, I would highly recommend that you do some soul searching to figure out what you want to do with your life. Make decisions for yourself, not anyone else. It’s so much more important to be happy in life than to follow someone else’s dreams. I personally am grateful that I was ‘pushed’ to go to college and guided to work at a good company but not because I enjoyed what I was doing but because it afforded me an opportunity to do what I’m doing with my life now. Anyway my point is that you have your whole life ahead of you and it’s a lot easier to figure out when you’re younger what really drives you (e.g. passions in life). You have an opportunity to do that now. I wish you the best of luck with whatever you decide.

Your question prompts me to think of my introduction speech that I have to my classes at the community college. I stated I have no problem in giving everybody As, I also have no problem giving everybody Fs; however, if I am giving everybody Fs, then there is something wrong with me as an instructor. A 1.7 GPA is composed of results from several classes, and is a warning indicator. At this point I suggest that one does honest introspection - is it partially because you are not getting enough to eat, is your home life distracting you from academics, are you trying to do too many extracurricular activities, are you partying too much, do you have undiagnosed learning disabilities, etc.? I definitely suggest the community college route because they have programs for at-risk students & testing for learning disabilities. A four year college is too ambitious given you have had some academic troubles already.

You should probably reconsider your desire to go to college. College is like High School but on steroids. Everything that made high school difficult will still exist in college but at a more challenging level. The exception is your home life. If you had abusive parents, were homeless, etc., perhaps you could do better living on your own or perhaps in a dorm. But if you struggled because the material was too difficult, or you were lazy and lacked self-discipline, run away from college and go to a trade school or apprenticeship. Don’t go to college because you believe you’re supposed to. Go because you are trying to make more money when you graduate. Pick a degree that will allow you to make more money. College is the second largest investment most of us will make in our entire lives, and we’re only 18 when we do it. Picking a worthless degree (history, gender studies, literature, sociology, etc.) or a degree that is too challenging for you to complete will set you back at least a decade.

Can I get into college with a 1.7 GPA, or should I do a community college first? Using common US standards, that is an exceptionally low GPA to start at any college. Are you sure you want to take 50+ more courses in four years? College is not for everyone. In fact, most people do not have a college degree and the world keeps spinning. Speaking as a three-time college dropout who took — ahem — the scenic route to get an AA, BS, MA and PhD, you can do it if you want it, but you gotta want it badly enough to take a bunch of courses that will not even count toward your degree. These will prepare you to be at the place everyone already started with. Community colleges are perfect for this.

i want to assume there’s a very good reason for your GPA being that low. if you want to go to college (are you sure you want to go to college?) the prestigious ones will probably not look at much after your grades (unless, as stated above, you have a pretty good reason for them being that low). i’d recommend community college first (and at LEAST a 3.5) before applying to bigger colleges. also gives you a chance at seeing whether you even want to go for a 4-year degree. whatever reason it is that you have a 1.7 may still be ongoing, and there is no point in you spending the time, effort, energy, and money applying for something you may either not complete, or end up hating.

If you are committed to going to college and understand why you want to go, then a community college is almost certainly your best choice. You should consider career and technical education (CTE, aka vo-tech) programs alongside AAS programs and transfer programs. Realize that you can spend a lot of time and money at community college, burn through one-time, limited financial aid (e.g., Pell grants), and rack up debt, all without moving toward the finish line. You are (presumably) graduating high school because the system causes that to happen. There is no equivalent “up and out” in any community college program; at best, you can get thrown out before wasting more money and time, but even that’s getting harder. I would start with one course. Freshman composition, probably. If you have a lot of energy, add in whatever mathematics course you place into. If you can’t maintain a 2.0 GPA, just stop. Rethink.

With that GPA, I would start at a community college. The transition is easier and smaller classes allow for more individual attention. There are also usually remedial classes in math and English, if you need them, that will allow you to gain the knowledge you may have missed in high school that will allow you to perform at the college level. You don’t provide information about why your GPA from high school is so low. I would give some serious thought and self-reflection about that and speak with the high school guidance counselor about it. If you spent your time socializing or on other distractions from school and didn’t apply yourself, then you will need to develop better habits to succeed even at community college. If the academic rigors were too much for you, you might discuss other alternatives to college such as technical or other occupational type schools with your guidance counselor. If you were in special education, speak with your counselor about the special programs and accomodations that may be available at your community college.

Why would you write a group of strangers about this? I doubt very seriously you will be accepted, but try and find out. With a GPA that low, I think remedial courses are in order before even considering college, even a Community college. Find out what the major principles you do not understand are and learn them. Also, with a GPA that low, perhaps your talents lie in other areas like a trade: cooking, plumbing, electrician, tailor etc. These positions pay well and are needed in our society.

My first thought is to ask whether you’re going to receive your high school diploma at all with that low an average. I would have thought that you’d need at least a 2.0 to get your diploma. Without that, you would, perhaps, only receive a certificate of attendance. I’d suggest you take some time off in the workplace to discover whether you learn that you would really like to get some further schooling. Next, you should seriously consider an area of education satisfied by a two year degree from a community college with an option to continue further after several more years in the workplace. Since community colleges offer a number of programs keyed to health sciences and the trades, you should be able to find an area of study with which you can succeed at a higher level, while discovering something you’d really like to pursue. Always remember that our system of education, unlike any other in the world, permits you to re-enter school at any time or age to pursue further study or to change professions and prepare for greater challenges. Your low grade point average in high school indicates, at least, a lack of motivation and maturity to pursue serious study. You must address this problem within yourself before you start seeking to reach any further academic heights. This doesn’t mean that you lack to potential, but you have yet to show anyone you can achieve academically. That means you have some work ahead of you.

A2A Give yourself a break. A 1.7 GPA is a C-. Most colleges would not be interested in you. Although you may be able to find a private college or institution that may accept you, you'll be paying more than you should and possibly fail, which would be a waste of your time and money. You may want to reconsider what it is that you want to do. If you really don't want to go to college, then don't. If you do want to go to college, then try a community college and see how that fits. There may be vocational classes or training offered that might fit your personality and skills. If you go to the community college, be sure to visit your advisor more often than you might have in high school.

You’ll get the course work, classes and tutorials needed by attending Community college and save a mint too. And for those who excell or even get bs unlike in high school you’ll usually get into a top 100 school like my oldest son did barely studying. For those who fully immerse themselves the sky is the limit so yes the art move and the place that has the best resources is comminity college. Smart question and good luck to you. You get a free reset!

I would recommend going to a Community College first, mainly because you probably need retooling your study habits and it will give you a clean slate. Also, your marks being a C- average your options for places that will accept you are not large. So, get your Associate’s degree and try to improve your GPA. Then give it a go.

Community college is probably your best option. Go, and work hard. Get an excellent GPA and that will be your credential for transfer to a good four year program. Your low high school GPA will then not matter.

I would recommend community college to find out if you can get your academic self on track. A C- average in HS shows a tremendous lack of effort or aptitude (for whatever reason). So spending a fortune to find out that college is not for you seems a poor choice to me. Prove yourself first, and then go on and get your bachelor’s degree if you find that you can handle getting your associate’s first.
If a mid C is all you can do, you might be better to work on foundation courses in Community College. It is cheaper than the same courses at a 4-year school.
Definitely go to a community college first. Work hard, get all As, and then apply to a four-year university for your junior year.
